text:
I had very little idea of
what the case method was.
I had heard of it.

Of course, HBS is famous for
it, but it was very, very hard

to understand what
it actually meant.

It turned out to be much more
inquiring, inquisitive, much

more of an adventure,
and an unknown,

and a big question mark at
the beginning of every case.

To be forced to
take on perspectives

that are your own, to walk in
a case-protagonist's shoes,

it's like your synapses
are always firing.

I can't count the
number of times

that I have walked in
on a Monday morning

and been faced with something
that felt like, oh, my god.

This is the introduction
to an HBS case.

Because of the case
method, it's like I

was in spring training
for two years,
and now, I'm in the big leagues.

And I have all the competencies,
and all the frameworks,

and the approaches to think
about how to solve problems.

Going to business school
is also about changing

the way you look at the world
by the people that you meet,

the experiences that
you get to have,

the cases that you
read the change the way
you thought about something.

I don't think I
really appreciated

the impact that business
school had on me
until now, 10 years later.

I've been in the shoes
of a protagonist who

had to make a
difficult decision,

and I've had the
luxury of hearing

all the different perspectives
from my classmates.

And so then when
I am that person,

I can just tackle it
as any other challenge.

The case method sticks because
you internalize the response,
the process, the outcome.

Put me in a room,
there might be someone

who's better at finance,
someone who's better at tech.

But for me, I'm really good at
getting to the heart of problem

and solving that with
a deliberate approach.

I knew that I would be a better
public speaker from the case

method, but I
didn't really expect

to come out with a true set of
tools to overcome insecurity.

Imposter syndrome
is still there,

but I feel like I can
silence the inner voice.

What the case method has really
taught me to value and to look
for is diversity of thought.

By listening to
what everyone things

and by contrasting a bunch
of different points of views,

that's where true
insight comes from.

I think it's really helped me
build a team because I know

that we get to a better
outcome when more voices

and experiences
are at the table.

Learning about the human story
behind the business statistics,

to understand strategy,
and marketing,

and finance with a
practical, applied context
brought the learning to life.

Business is not just about
understanding companies.

It's an approach for
understanding the world.
